author: @EssDubz
text: In no existing framework anyway does max pooling round up the output dimension size. If stride takes you off the edge, you don't include it. The output dimension for a 3x3 image, with a kernel  size of 2, and stride of 2, is 1x1

author: @MrAyandebnath
text: @krish Naik...You are aweosme and a great teacher. But you explained max pooling wrong. The example you used provided 4 as max value for the last quadrant you used, it should be 8 not 4. The concept of max pooling doesn't use stride 2. The concept is well written in https://towardsdatascience.com/a-comprehensive-guide-to-convolutional-neural-networks-the-eli5-way-3bd2b1164a53 I am not criticizin Krish, just wanted to let you know the right method.

author: @mukund198526
text: Really so simply explained and now see the difference how a upgrad professor explained the same concept -   Max pooling: If any one of the patches says something strongly about the presence of a certain feature, then the pooling layer counts that feature as 'detected'. Average pooling: If one patch says something very firmly but the other ones disagree,  the pooling layer takes the average to find out.
